NiPrefs is a library that offers a preferences-system in a text file within a table-like structure. It stores the preferences in an OrderedTable[string, PrefsNode] where PrefsNode is an object variation that supports the following types:

  • int
  • nil
  • seq (there are no arrays)
  • bool
  • char
  • float
  • string (and raw strings)
  • OrderedTable[string, PrefsNode] (nested tables)

Syntax

NiPrefs writes the preferences down to a text file using a pretty straightforward syntax that goes like this:

# Comment
# key=val
lang="en" # Keys do not require quotes
dark=false
scheme=> # Nested tables are defined with a greater than symbol and indentation-in
  background="#ffffff" # background belongs to scheme
  font=>
    family="UbuntuMono" # scheme/font/family
    size=15
    color="#000000"

Basic usage

Example:

import niprefs

let defaultPrefs = toPrefs { # The default prefs are used the first time or when the preferences file gets removed.
  "lang": "en",
  "dark": true,
  "keybindings": {:},
  "scheme": {
    "background": "#000000",
    "font": {
      "size": 15,
      "family": "UbuntuMono",
      "color": "#73D216"
    }
  }
}

var prefs = initPrefs(defaultPrefs, "settings.niprefs")

After the above example, a new settings.niprefs file should be created:

#NiPrefs
lang="en"
dark=true
keybindings={:}
scheme=>
  background="#000000"
  font=>
    size=15
    family="UbuntuMono"
    color="#73D216"

Reading

To read a key from your preferences file you can access to it as it were a table:

echo prefs["lang"]
>>> "en"
To read a nested key you must use something called key paths, which are in essence a path to a nested key separated by a slash /:

echo prefs["scheme/font/family"] # Same as prefs["scheme"]["font"]["family"]
>>> "UbuntuMono"

Writing

To change the value of a key or create a new one you can do it as it were table:

prefs["lang"] = "es"
echo prefs["lang"]
>>> "es"
Same with nested keys:

prefs["scheme/font/size"] = 20 # prefs["scheme"]["font"]["size"] = 20 wont' work
echo prefs["scheme/font/size"]
>>> 20

Removing

To remove a key from your preferences you can use either del or pop:

  • del deletes the key if it exists, does nothing if it does not.
  • pop deletes the key, returns true if it existed and sets val to the value that the key had. Otherwise, returns false, and val is unchanged.

prefs.del("lang")
assert "lang" notin prefs

var val: PrefsNode
prefs.pop("scheme/font/size")
assert val == 20

More

There are more useful procedures.

Check them here:

  • writeMany
  • clear
  • overwrite
  • delete
  • parsePrefs
  • readPrefs

Imports

niprefs/prefsbase

Types

Prefs = object of PrefsBase
Provides a table-like interface for the PrefsBase object

Procs

proc `$`(prefs: Prefs): string {....raises: [Exception, SyntaxError, ValueError,
    KeyError, NPegException, IOError], tags: [RootEffect, ReadIOEffect].}
Instead of printing the prefs object, print it's content

Example:

var prefs = toPrefs({"lang": "en", "theme": "dark"}).initPrefs

prefs.overwrite() # To avoid conflicts

assert $prefs == "{\"lang\": \"en\", \"theme\": \"dark\"}"
proc `[]=`(prefs: Prefs; key: string; val: PrefsNode) {....raises: [OSError,
    IOError, ValueError, InvalidKey, KeyError, Exception, SyntaxError,
    NPegException], tags: [ReadDirEffect, ReadEnvEffect, ReadIOEffect,
                           WriteDirEffect, WriteIOEffect, RootEffect].}

Write in the prefs file the given key-value pair.

Use this procedure for structured types with the toPrefs macro.

(See the example below)

Supports key path.

Example:

var prefs = toPrefs({"lang": "en"}).initPrefs

prefs["keybindings"] = toPrefs @[{"keys": "Ctrl+C",
    "command": "copy"}]
# It is converted into
# newPNode(@[newPNode(
#   {
#     "keys": newPNode("Ctrl+C"),
#     "command": newPNode("copy")
#   }.toOrderedTable
# )])
proc `[]=`[T: not PrefsNode](prefs: Prefs; key: string; val: T)

Write in the prefs file the given key-value pair.

newPNode is called on val, meaning that only the structured types require PrefsNode type.

For structured types use `[]=`(prefs: Prefs, key: string: val: PrefsNode).

(See the example below)

Supports key path.

Example:

var prefs = toPrefs({"lang": "en", "theme": "dark"}).initPrefs

prefs.overwrite() # To avoid conflicts

prefs["lang"] = "es" # newPString("es") is not required, since `string` is not a structured type
proc `[]`(prefs: Prefs; key: string): PrefsNode {....raises: [KeyError, Exception,
    SyntaxError, ValueError, NPegException, IOError],
    tags: [RootEffect, ReadIOEffect].}

Get a key from the prefs file reading it

Supports key path.

Example:

var prefs = toPrefs({"lang": "en", "scheme": {
    "font": "UbuntuMono"}}).initPrefs

prefs.overwrite() # To avoid conflicts

assert prefs["lang"] == "en" # newPNode("en") is not required
assert prefs["scheme/font"] == "UbuntuMono"
proc clear(prefs: Prefs) {....raises: [OSError, IOError, ValueError, InvalidKey], tags: [
    ReadDirEffect, ReadEnvEffect, ReadIOEffect, WriteDirEffect, WriteIOEffect].}
Clears the content of the file.

Example:

var prefs = toPrefs({"lang": "en", "theme": "dark"}).initPrefs
prefs.clear()
assert prefs.content == default PObjectType # PObject stands for OrderedTable[string, PrefsNode]
proc contains(prefs: Prefs; key: string): bool {.
    ...raises: [IOError, Exception, SyntaxError, ValueError, NPegException],
    tags: [RootEffect, ReadIOEffect].}
Alias of hasKey proc for use with the in operator.

Example:

var prefs = toPrefs({"lang": "en", "theme": "dark"}).initPrefs
prefs.overwrite() # To avoid conflicts

assert "lang" in prefs
proc del(prefs: Prefs; key: string) {....raises: [Exception, SyntaxError,
    ValueError, KeyError, NPegException, IOError, OSError, InvalidKey], tags: [
    RootEffect, ReadIOEffect, ReadDirEffect, ReadEnvEffect, WriteDirEffect,
    WriteIOEffect].}
Deletes key from the prefs file. Does nothing if the key does not exist. 
proc initPrefs(table: PObjectType = default PObjectType;
               path: string = "prefs.niprefs"): Prefs {.
    ...raises: [OSError, IOError, ValueError, InvalidKey], tags: [ReadDirEffect,
    ReadEnvEffect, ReadIOEffect, WriteDirEffect, WriteIOEffect].}
Creates a new Prefs object and checks if a file exists at path to create it if it doesn't. 
proc initPrefs(table: PrefsNode = newPObject(); path: string = "prefs.niprefs"): Prefs {.
    ...raises: [OSError, IOError, ValueError, InvalidKey], tags: [ReadDirEffect,
    ReadEnvEffect, ReadIOEffect, WriteDirEffect, WriteIOEffect].}
Creates a new Prefs object and checks if a file exists at path to create it if it doesn't. 
proc pop(prefs: Prefs; key: string; val: var PrefsNode): bool {....raises: [
    IOError, Exception, SyntaxError, ValueError, NPegException, KeyError,
    OSError, InvalidKey], tags: [RootEffect, ReadIOEffect, ReadDirEffect,
                                 ReadEnvEffect, WriteDirEffect, WriteIOEffect].}
Deletes the key from the prefs file. Returns true, if the key existed, and sets val to the mapping of the key. Otherwise, returns false, and the val is unchanged.

Example:

var
  prefs = toPrefs({"lang": "en", "theme": "dark"}).initPrefs
  s: PrefsNode

prefs.overwrite() # To avoid conflicts

assert prefs.pop("lang", s) == true
assert "lang" notin prefs
assert s.getString() == "en"

Templates

template keys(prefs: Prefs)
Same as prefs.content.keys 
template len(prefs: Prefs): int
Same as prefs.content.len.

Example:

var prefs = toPrefs({"lang": "en", "theme": "dark"}).initPrefs

prefs.overwrite() # To avoid conflicts

assert prefs.len == 2
template pairs(prefs: Prefs)
Same as prefs.content.pairs 
template values(prefs: Prefs)
Same as prefs.content.values

Exports

writeMany, parsePrefs, newPChar, isNil, PSeqParam, newPNode, parsePrefs, ==, newPEmpty, write, content, newPChar, getChar, $, newPFloat, [], newPNode, InvalidKey, initPrefsBase, newPNil, newPNode, delete, hasKey, newPNode, PrefsNodeObj, del, writeMany, PrefsNKind, newPNode, checkFile, newPNode, newPBool, toPrefs, overwrite, PrefsNode, toPTree, getInt, []=, isEmpty, read, create, toPTree, newPNode, PObjectType, newPSeq, newPInt, initPrefsBase, ==, getFloat, []=, PSeqType, PrefsBase, get, [], write, overwrite, getBool, getSeq, getString, delKey, getObject, readPrefs, [], newPString, newPObject, []
